metadata.title: 5 Data Structures to Master in R if you want to be a Data Scientist | by Linda Ngo | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: 5 Data Structures to Master in R if you want to be a Data Scientist
metadata.description: To become an R data scientist, you will need to master the basics of this widely used open source language, including factors, lists, and data frames. After mastering these data structures, you’ll be…

all_paragraphs: To become an R data scientist, you will need to master the basics of this widely used open source language, including factors, lists, and data frames. After mastering these data structures, you’ll be ready to undertake your first very own data analysis!
Read until the end for a cheat-sheet of the data types.
Before we start with the data structures, it is important to take a look at the basic data types that make up some of the elements in these data structures.

If you want to get more in-depth with the basics in R, check out this article I wrote which teaches you how to calculate, assign variables, and work with the basic data types. It includes practice problems to work on too!
Vectors are one-dimensional arrays that can store any of the basic data types, including numerics, logicals, and characters.
To create a vector, use the combine function c() with the elements separated by a comma between the parenthesis.
Naming a vector gives a name to the vector elements. It can be done using the name function names().
If we want to select a single element from a vector, we simply put in the index of the element we want to select between square brackets.
To select multiple elements from a vector, indicate which elements should be selected using a vector within the square brackets.
We can also use the names of the elements instead of their numeric position.

If you want to get more in-depth with vectors, check out this article I wrote on how to create, name, select, and compare vectors. By the end of it, you’ll learn how to analyze gaming results using vectors!

A matrix is a collection of elements of the same data type (numeric, character, or logical) arranged into a fixed number of rows and columns. A two-dimensional matrix is one that works only with rows and columns.
Thematrix() function creates a matrix. There are three important arguments to this function:
To add names to the rows and columns we can use the functions colnames() and rownames().
We can also use the dimnames attribute and directly name the matrix during creation.
We can add a column or multiple to a matrix using the cbind() to merge matrices and/or vectors together by column.
To add a row, we use the rbind() function to take a sequence of vectors or matrices and combine them by row.
We can use rowSums() to calculate the sum of each row, and colSums() to calculate the sum of each column.
Square brackets [] are used to select one or multiple elements from a matrix. Since matrices are two-dimensional, a comma is needed to separate rows and columns.
If you want to get more in-depth with matrices, check out this article I wrote on how to create, name, select, and do basic computations with matrices. It even includes practice problems to do!

A factor is used to store categorical variables. Categorical variables belong to a limited number of categories (e.g., “male”, “female”). They are the opposite of continuous variables which can correspond to an infinite number of values.
To create a factor, use the factor() function, which encodes a vector a vector as a factor (also referred to as “category” or “enumerated type”).
A nominal categorical variable does not have an implied order (e.g. “Elephant”, “Monkey”, “Horse”). An ordinal categorical variable has a natural ordering/ranking (e.g. “Low”, “Medium”, “High”).
R constructs and prints them differently. By default, the factor() function transforms the vector into an unordered factor. To create an ordered factor, we need two additional arguments:
For ordinal variables, order is indicated using <.

Sometimes, it can be helpful to change the names of specific factor levels in a data set for clarity or other reasons. For example, suppose the raw data from a survey contains a question about the respondent’s gender with just two categories recorded: "M" and "F". Recording abbreviations may be convenient during data collection, but they can become confusing during the analysis. We can change the name of levels by using the levels() function:

Caution: The order in which levels are assigned is important. levels(survey_factor) outputs [1] "F" "M". If the factor levels are not specified during creation, they will automatically be assigned alphabetically. To correctly map "F" to "Female" and "M" to "Male", the levels need to be set to c("Female", "Male"), in that particular order.
The summary() function gives a quick overview of the contents of a variable. It can be used for factors to determine how many responses of each factor level we have in our vector.

If you want to get more in-depth with factors, check out this article I wrote on how to create, subset, and compare factors. It includes practice problems so you can practice your newly developed skills.

Data frames are like matrices but the elements don’t all have to be the same data type. A data frame has its variables as its columns (e.g. married, age), and the observations as rows (e.g. respondent1, respondent2 , …).
We can inspect an element by using the following functions to show a small part of the entire frame:
We can also use the str() function to show the structure of the frame, getting the following information:

To construct a data frame, we use the data.frame() function with the data vectors passed as arguments as the different columns. Note that every column has the same length in a data frame, so the vectors passed should also have the same length. They don’t need to be the same data type though.
Similar to vectors and matrices, we use square brackets [] to select elements. A comma is used to indicate what to select from rows and columns respectively.
We can use theorder() function to sort data based on a certain data frame variable.
If you want to get more in-depth with data frames, check out this article I wrote on how to create, select, and order data frames, with practice problems to further solidify your learning.

Lists can hold components of different objects, such as matrices, vectors, data frames, and other lists, gathered under one name (the name of the list) in an ordered fashion. None of the objects need to be related in anyway, as such, practically anything can be stored in a list.
We use the function list() to construct a list:
We can give names to list components so they what they stand for don’t be forgotten. We can either name them during the construction of the list or afterwards. For example,
We can use the numbered position of the component along with double square brackets [[]] as opposed to single square brackets [] used for vectors and matrices.
